Say you have an average woman. She has no control over her life. She has little or nothing in the way of a resource for being good to herself, even when it is necessary. She has family and animals and friends and associates that depend on her for sustenance of all kinds. She rarely has adequate sleep or rest; she has no time for herself, no space of her own, little or no money to buy things for herself, no opportunity to consider her own emotional needs. She is at the beck and call of others, because she has these responsibilities and obligations and does not choose to (or cannot) abandon them. For such a woman, the one and only thing she is likely to have a little control over for indulging her own self is FOOD. When such a woman overeats, the verb for that is "doroledim". (And then she feels guilty, because there are women whose children are starving and who do not have even THAT option for self-indulgence... ) Suzette Haden Elginburden Suzette Haden Elginto follow Suzette Haden Elginto enable, to make possible or easy [dó=cause-to + thad=to be able] Suzette Haden Elginenabler, one who enables, makes things possible or easy [dó=cause-to + thad=to be able + á=suffix for doer] Suzette Haden Elginto enable another to persist in self-destructive behavior (for instance substance abuse) by providing excuses or by helping that individual avoid the consequences of such behavior [dó-=cause-to + thad=to be able + -(e)lh=pejorative] Suzette Haden Elginenabler, one who enables another to persist in self-destructive behavior (for instance substance abuse) by providing excuses or by helping that individual avoid the consequences of such behavior [dó-=cause-to + thad=to be able + -(e)lh-=pejorative + -á=suffix for doer] Sharla Hardyoak [do=strong + yáanin=tree] Amberwind Barnhartprotect, shield, safeguard [dó- =cause to + yom=be safe] Suzette Haden Elginapple [do=strong + yu=fruit] Suzette Haden Elginto give rest, to refresh Suzette Haden Elginfox [mid=creature] Suzette Haden Elginmeadow, field Suzette Haden Elginfriendliness for bad reasons, to be friendly (dehena, dena, dina, dona= friendliness) Suzette Haden Elginto have to, to be obliged to Suzette Haden Elginto use Suzette Haden Elginto heal Suzette Haden Elginhealer [dutha=to heal + -á=suffix for doer] Suzette Haden Elginbandage, to bandage [dutha=to heal + od=cloth] Suzette Haden Elginhospital [dutha=to heal + hoth=place] Suzette Haden Elginambulance [dutha=to heal + mazh=car] Suzette Haden Elginanesthesia [dutha+wish] Sharla Hardyherbal remedy DKdepression as a side effect of medication Suzette Haden Elginor, either Suzette Haden Elginto buy, to sell Suzette Haden Elginspouse ("Bíi eril X i Y meheba wa." ("Athid is at the hotel.); Case Marker: suffix for place (see also '-sha') Suzette Haden ElginEmbedding Marker: to embed a relative clause (like English "I know the womah who is tired") attached to the last element in the embedded clause (see also '-hé', '-hée') Suzette Haden Elginprefix to signify child, youth, young creature, general prefix for offspring (see á-, yáa-) Suzette Haden ElginDegree Marker: to an extraordinary degree (see also '-hil', '-hal', '-hul', '-hel') Suzette Haden ElginDegree Marker: to an unusual degree, very (see also '-hil', '-hel', '-hul', '-háalish') -hé morpheme used to embed one statement inside another statement; Embedding Marker: to embed a sentential complement (like English "I know that she left") attached to the last element in the embedded clause (see also '-háa', '-hée') When we want to put one English statement inside another one -- a process called "embedding" -- we can use the word "that" to mark the statement that is embedded. For example, "I know that science fiction conventions are fun," embeds the statement "science fiction conventions are fun" inside "I know [some other statement]," by putting "that" at the beginning of the embedded statement. LAadan embeds one statement in another by putting the morpheme "-hE" on the last word of the embedded statement. So, in sentence #7, the statement "radezhehul thod Aabeth" -- "writing a book is very hard," is marked as an embedded statement by adding "-hE" to "Aabeth." [Note: An embedding morpheme is the _only_ morpheme that can follow a case-marking morpheme.]

The addition of "lh" need not create an actual new word; for example, "awith " means "baby"-to use instead "lhawith" (or awithelh") means only something like "the darned baby" and is ordinarily a temporary addition. But it is very handy indeed. We are indebted to the Navajo language for this device. ("Athid has a suitcase."); Case Marker: suffix for object Suzette Haden ElginSpeech Act suffix; "said in pain" Suzette Haden ElginCase Marker: suffix for possession - by reason of birth (see also '-thi', '-the', '-thu', '-tho') Suzette Haden ElginCase Marker: suffix for possession - for unknown or unacknowledged reasons (see also '-tha', '-thi', '-thu', '-tho') Suzette Haden Elginabout-to-VERB any minute prefix Suzette Haden Elginabout-to-VERB, potentially, but not "any minute" Suzette Haden ElginCase Marker: suffix for possession - by reason of chance (see also '-tha', '-the', '-thu', '-tho') Suzette Haden ElginCase Marker: suffix for possession - other (purchase, gift, law, custom, etc.) (see also '-tha', '-the', '-thi', '-thu') Suzette Haden Elginto-have-just-VERBED prefix Suzette Haden ElginCase Marker: suffix for possession - partitive (false possessive) (see also '-thi', '-the', '-thu', '-tha') Suzette Haden Elgina morpheme meaning "the reason for which something is done"; Case Marker: suffix for cause - reason, due to, because of (see also '-wan') Suzette Haden ElginCase Marker: suffix for cause - for the purpose of, in order to (see also '-wáan') Suzette Haden Elginchanges a verb to an adjective, must be put on both verb and noun, after plural marker (beautiful woman = woháya wowith) Láadan has a form that is much like an English "adjective + noun" sequence, as in "green tree" or "small child". You can take any sequence of verb and subject (remembering that "adjectives" are only ordinary verbs in Láadan) and but the marker "wo-" at the beginning of each one. "Beautiful woman" is thus "woháya wowith". This is very useful, but it is a bit different from English, because it can only be used if you have just one verb. You cannot use this pattern to translate an English sequence like "little red brick wall". To make your descriptive phrase plural, you would put the plural marker "me-" at the beginning of the verb, as always. "Busy dragons" would be "mewoshOod wohOowamid." Amberwind’s Láadan lessonsIf the stone is hard, then the minerals will remain inside it.“ébre” = then, “aril” = future, “ná-” = to continue to, “ham” = to be present, “bad” = mineral, “be” = it, “-ha” = location marker, “nil” = inside. The woman is beautiful (my perception). The women are beautiful and good (my perception). The pillow and the grass are beautiful. Ann and Bethany are menopausing (I’m told). The woman is good (according to my perceptions). The creature is not good (I’m told). You speak, I hear. The bread is red (I hear from a trusted source). The bread is not red (according to my perceptions). The bread is not red (obviously—because it is present for the speaker and hearer to examine). Who/what is good? Is peace good? Who/what is beautiful? Who/what teaches? The weather is not good. The weather is bad. Doesn’t the cat want the grain? What doesn’t the cat want? The parents help me. Who (plural) helps me? Whom do the parents help? I am amazed. The woman causes me to be amazed (The woman amazes me.) I help Margaret. Whom does Margaret help? Who helps Margaret? The woman tries to be strong. The woman brings/takes the kettle. The woman brings/takes the old kettle. You will work. Some day, you will work. Let’s suppose you worked.... I am a extremely good person. I am a good person. I am a teacher and a parent. What is peace? Is peace safety? Teaching is understanding. I want (food). I want to speak. We will understand. We will be able to understand. You might eat. I began to teach. Are the hands clean? Are your (by birth) hands clean? The cats are not old. Her (by chance) cats are not old. A bird ate fruit. I need the light of (no real ownership) the sun. The woman travels. The woman travels from the park. The man bought (or sold) the pig. The man bought the pig from the baker. Did you (many) come (or go)? I moved the food. I moved the food from the dish. I moved the food from your dish. I taught (to) you. I will carry bread to the house. I followed the cat. I followed the cat from my home. I followed the cat from my home along the road. I followed the cat from my home to the forest along the road. The parents teach peace with (using) harmony and with (using) language. She comes/goes from the mountain with (using) my boat. She travels to the water with a cat. She’s learning Láadan with her cousin (pleasurably). With whom is she learning Láadan? There are many birds in the sky. The boat is (present) on the water. I work around my home. I work at my home. I work at night. I work during the night. I always work. I work when I need to work. When do you work? I begin working at dawn. I work through the morning. I work through the morning. I stop working at sunset. I’m going home (in order) to eat. Is she going home (in order) to sleep? Why (for what purpose) are you going home? The book is red. The book is RED, not yellow. The BOOK is red, not the writing implement. The book WAS red; now it’s yellow. Margaret sold me a pearl. MARGARET sold me a pearl! Margaret sold me a PEARL! Margaret sold ME a pearl! I think [the woman is beautiful]. I don’t think [the woman is beautiful]. I hope [it’s starting to rain]. I hope [it’s finished raining]. I hope [it’s not raining]. I want [Anna have a pearl]. I want Anna to have a pearl. She works so (in order that) [her family will be able to eat]. I bought a pearl so (in order) that [I am able to give it to my spouse]. I bought a pearl so I would be able, now, to give it to my spouse. Be important [Anna have a pearl]. It’s important for Anna to have a pearl. Do you know [has it finished raining?]? Who knows [the pigs are clean]? Who knows that the pigs are clean? Who knows [are the pigs clean?]? Who knows whether the pigs are clean? He knows a woman who sings. The woman sings. He knows a woman. I feel friendliness (for good reason). I feel joy (for foolish reason). I feel contentment (for bad reason). I feel respect (for no reason at all). I feel gratitude (despite negative circumstances). I feel grief which is for good reason, for which I can blame no one and about which I can do nothing. She felt frustration for which there was no reason, so of course she could not blame anyone, but she could do something about the situation. Will you be angry (reason, blame, no remedy) with me when I leave? No, I shall feel regret (reason, no blame, no remedy) then. The birds are quite colorful like the flowers are very colorful. The birds, like the flowers, are very colorful. The fruit are high, and the flowers are very high, but the leaves are scarcely high. The fruit is high. The leaf is high. The leaf surpasses. The leaf is higher than the fruit. A cat and the insect are small. The insect surpasses. The insect is smaller than a cat. The leaf and the flower are red (obviously); does the flower surpass? Is the flower redder than the leaf? The leaf and the flower are red (obviously); what surpasses? Which is redder, the flower or the leaf? I am trying to be a teacher. I am trying in vain to be a teacher. I want to be a teacher. The students want to be teachers. I want to be a teacher again. No-one knows whether I am a teacher. No-one knows whether I failed to be a teacher. The cat is eating a fish. A fish is being eaten by the cat. A fish is being eaten. Mary wlll count the money. The money will be counted by Mary. The money will be counted. The building is trivially tall. The building is tall to a minor degree. The building is tall (to unspecified degree). The building is much tall. The building is unusually tall. The building is greatly tall. The building is extremely tall. The building is extraordinarily tall. The flowers are trivially fragrant. The flowers are fragrant to a minor degree. The flowers are fragrant (to unspecified degree). The flowers are much fragrant. The flowers are fragrant to a pleasing degree. The flowers are unusually fragrant. The flowers are greatly fragrant. The flowers are fragrant to an excellent degree. The flowers are magnificently fragrant. The flowers are extremely fragrant. The flowers are extraordinarily fragrant. The flowers are fragrant to a perfect degree. It (the weather) is not nearly warm enough. It’s not quite warm enough. It’s warm (to unspecified degree). It’s troublesomely (slightly too) warm. It’s unusually (a bit too) warm. It’s severely (too) hot. It’s violently (too) hot. It’s extraordinarily (too) hot. It’s intolerably (too) hot. It’s so hot, I’m going to have to do something rash is someone doesn’t help! I am going home. I keep going home again and again (but with no particular pattern to my visits). The stars move in the sky. The stars move in the sky (every night, despite what humans may think or try to do about it). I clean house. I clean house regularly (eg weekly: arbitrary period set by humans). I eat in the morning. I eat every morning (by analogy to pattern of nature). I eat regularly (in a pattern by analogy to nature). The wind blows. The wind blows again and again (in what seems to be a pattern, but cannot be demonstrated or proved to be one). Is the woman meditating (in a state of meditation)? No, she’s hypnotized (in a state of hypnotic trance). The woman entered (began to be in) a state of numb shock when her spouse died. The bewildered woman will speak to us (few) at sunset. The woman danced ecstatically (in a manner as though being in a state of ecstasy).
